unkerpaulie

its no secret that there are a lot of discrepancies between the bible (which is considered as absolute truth) and science (which is also considered as absolute truth). there are some that maintain the bible as overriding anything else, others that hold no regard for the bible at all, and still some that are willing to accept the bible partially (God exists, christianity is valid, etc) while letting science overrule in some or all instances of contradiction. basically, you have 3 categories:
 
 1. the bible only - fundamentalists, yec's, etc
 2. science only - atheists, darwinists, etc
 3. both are valid - many categories, this is the "belly" of the bell curve
 
 for those in category 3, willing to yield in the way of emperical evidence, yet regarding the bible as true (to any extent), how can these contradictions be rectified? how can the bible be at all valid if it contains untruths?
 
 furthermore, how can the fundamentalist be ridiculed for completely rejecting science and maintaining their regard for the bible? and how can the atheist be judged for accepting science and completely rejecting the bible?

post_info.post_title: Science and the Bible: friends or foes?

zelma

 has been proven wrong by science, or gives contradictory evidence to itself.
 I am not saying I can discuss it effectively, but some examples would help. I am thinking the contradictory issues might be an instance of interpretation and up for grabs as far as who is right.
jitobear

Neither?
 
 Science is a study of the physical world/universe.
 
 The Bible is a guide to life and God.
 
 It's cool when they match (and they do here and there) - but using the Bible as a science text is mis-use.
unkerpaulie

science contradicts the how of the origin of life on earth, the probability of miracles and notion that God directly controls natural phenomenon
 
 jito, the bible is considered as absolute truth. if something other than the bible makes a statement that contradicts the bible, then either it is false, or the bible is false. both cannot be true.
Alan Ryan

Very simply, science gives, or aims to give, an empirical account of the natural world. Knowledge acquired by scientific method is thus fundamentally distinct from received authority or mere subjective assertion on questions of what is the case (i.e. reality).
 
 The Bible is a record of events and teachings (supposedly from God's self revelation) that guides the seeker after "religious truth". 
 
 It is not the task of science to contradict the metaphysical propositions that have a "Biblical authority".
Big_Bear_Scot

It also depends whether you believe that some of the Bible is an allegory, or that is a Literal account of what actually happened for example that God created the Earth in 7 days.
 
 Obviously if you believe in the Literal reading of the creation story then all the scientific evidence we have found so far contradicts this. 
 
 I posted some links in the Evolution forum of a Church of Scotland Minister's lectures on Science and Religion, I think it would be useful to this debate to post them.
 
 http://www.greekthomsonchurch.com/sermons/Science01.pdf 
 
 The minister in question is senior member of the Scottish Church, and he quotes many Scientific figures and Religious which explain some of their views on Religion and Science.

It is not the task of science to contradict the metaphysical propositions that have a "Biblical authority".

 no, not science's task. however, science often finds itself in a position of contradicting the bible. the bible attempts to describe many events and explain many phenomenon, most of which, upon investigation, seem to disagree with reality according to science. 
 
 the problem i am trying to address is how do christians that subscribe to evolution, or to the idea that biblical events are only allegorical fables, maintain the bible as a reliable source of truth?

Mach

and science (which is also considered as absolute truth).
 
 furthermore, how can the fundamentalist be ridiculed for completely rejecting science and maintaining their regard for the bible? and how can the atheist be judged for accepting science and completely rejecting the bible?

 
 People are friend or foe, have respect or don't have respect, etc. Science is just a body of knowledge. Some teachings of religion are not classified as "knowledge", they are "dogma", like much of christianity. Some othere religions are based more on spirituality, or philosophy, centering around wisdom and knowledge, these can in many ways, be religions based on "knowledge" or science. It all depends on what flavor of mythology we're discussing. So science and religions in that way, are not mutually exclsuive, there is not dichotomy.
 
 
 #1 Your statement that science is considered as absolute truth is misleading. I'm quite certain that rational individuals, both rational scientists and non-scientists (i.e. thinking people) regards all science as falsifiable based on evidence. Else, it wouldn't be science. If scientific claims were all "absolutes", they wouldn't need evidence, it would be similar to the bible in that scientists would publish "absolutes", and disagreeing or agreeing would be irrelevant. There also wouldn't be a scientific "method", peer review, experimentation....none of this would have any meaning. 
 
 #2 Fundamentalists can be ridiculed because they believe in ridiculous things, for ridiculous reasons. Is there some other reason to ridicule someone?
 Is ridiculing constructive? Probably not, it's an emotional release. The best way I know of to combat the problem of ignorance is through education.
 
 #3 Your average atheists rejects things that are irrational, or are not shown, through evidence, to be true. Judge this however you like, it's rational defensible. The bible, for instance, is not.
 
 -Mach
Mach

Neither?
 
 Science is a study of the physical world/universe.
 
 The Bible is a guide to life and God.
 
 It's cool when they match (and they do here and there) - but using the Bible as a science text is mis-use.

 
 Sums it up in a few short sentences, nicely done.
 
 -Mach
Alan Ryan

no, not science's task. however, science often finds itself in a position of contradicting the bible. the bible attempts to describe many events and explain many phenomenon, most of which, upon investigation, seem to disagree with reality according to science. 
 
 the problem i am trying to address is how do christians that subscribe to evolution, or to the idea that biblical events are only allegorical fables, maintain the bible as a reliable source of truth?

 
 Generally speaking, I would say that scientists are indifferent to the claims made in the Bible except in the particular cases where "religious" answers are given to questions that belong to science. Obvious examples are the fanciful cosmology of the Bible and its account of the origins of life - which are certainly contradicted by physics and evolutionary biology. 
 
 Science is not concerned with metaphysical claims like (for instance) God is a trinity consisting of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. I suppose that the "miracles" recorded in the Bible might be subjected to scientific scrutiny; but I've never come across any scientific critique of Jesus walking on water that proved its impossibility by reference to gravity, relative density, or the conditions of buoyancy etc. Scientists just don't bother addressing such non problems by the appliance of science.

Prophecies of the Great Pyramid by Raymond Gutierrez is one book that provides a lot of information regarding the chambers, halls and the recorded time frames and events that clearly conform with Biblical teaching.  emoticon_wow 
 
 Does the ' :p ' mean you're joking? You're not serious are you?
 
 An 'ape' is a classification of animal not 'a' animal...
 
 Gorillas, Chimpanzees, Orangutans, and Humans, are all 'great apes' (family Hominidae). The other ape family - Hylobatidae - consists basically of Gibbons and is known as the 'lesser apes'.
 
 The above great apes all had a common ancestor, that ancestor species doesn't exist anymore because it evolved into many different species.
 
 Man didn't evolve from chimps (for example) for goodness sake... chimps are like our evolutionary 'cousins' if you'd like an analogy not our evolutionary fathers...
 
 Again if you weren't joking I'm shocked and dismayed... emoticon_frazzled Can I ask in which country you were educated?

which brings us to a specific issue that we can discuss where science (i.e., evolution) and christianity comes head to head: man in God's image
 
 christians believe that God made man in his image, even if they consider genesis as "allegorical". this would imply that God has the appearance or resemblance of humans, in some way or the other. scriptures seem to confirm this by mentioning instances where God's hand or back was seen. 
 
 evolution tells us that man, when he was originally "created" millions of years ago, at one point did not resemble modern day humans at all. in fact, if we go all the way back to the root of evolution - the single common ancestor of ALL forms of life on the planet - then there were no such things as hands and back
 
 was man in the image and likeness of God back then? was it that God was "guiding" evolution to ensure that humans ended up looking like him? a "guided" evolution is inconsistent with science, mind you. so did God have the same image and likeness all along? or did it evolve at the same pace as humans? how could we be in the image and likeness of an eternal and constant God when scince has shown that our own image and likeness has continuously been changing?

Is evolution a scientific hypothesis? No scientist observed the the initial one celled matter that began changing and evolving from inorganic matter and at some point became alive. So how do you know it happened like that? How did unlife produce life?
 
 
 Evolution is a Theory not a hypothesis, a hypothesis is an educated guess based on Observation, which not has been proven yet. 
 A Theory is an explanation of set of Observations or events based on a proven Hypothesis and verified multiple times by independent groups of Scientists or researchers.
 
 The other thing I need to point out Evolution is not a Scientific theory that explains the origin of life, Evolution is the process of observing the changes of existing life over time. Darwin's original work was called the Origin of The Species not the Origin of Life.
 
 There are another group of theories(or Hypothesis) that deal with the Origin of Life such as Abiogenesis, RNA World, Clay Theory, Extraterrestrial and Intelligent Design.
 
 I don't want to clutter this religious forum with Science so if anyone is interested in these term in relation to the Origin of Life can google them, but for an explanation of how Organic compounds can be created from inorganic compounds see this  link. This experiment attempt to mimic the conditions of primordial Earth and then observe the results.
 
 The above Hypothesises IMHO don't invalidate the existence of God, so I can say that these hypothesises are compatible with having a belief of God.

 Is evolution a scientific hypothesis? No scientist observed the the initial one celled matter that began changing and evolving from inorganic matter and at some point became alive. So how do you know it happened like that? How did unlife produce life?

 
 Of course, you are mixing up abiogensis with evolution. There is no official 'theory' of abiogenesis, but research is being conducted on ways that it 
 very well could have happened. THere are probably multiple paths it might have taken, so any one path is not provable as 'THE' path it took on this planet.
 
 Evolution is a scientific theory. It is testable, and the principles are repeatable under labortory conditions when it comes to variations. There also is the forencs on fossils.
